name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: [SOUND] This lecture is about

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: natural language content analysis.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _As you see from this picture

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: this is really the first step to process any text data.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Text data are in natural languages.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: computers have to understand natural languages to some extent in _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _order to make use of the data
column6: so that's the topic of this lecture. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We're going to cover three things.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _First
column6: what is natural language processing
column7: which is a main technique for _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: processing natural language to obtain understanding?

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _The second is the State of the Art in NLP
column6: which stands for _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: natural language processing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Finally
column6: we're going to cover the relation between natural language processing and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: text retrieval.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _First
column6: what is NLP? _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Well
column6: the best way to explain it is to think about

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: if you see a text in a foreign language that you can't understand.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now
column6: what you have to do in order to understand that text? _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: This is basically what computers are facing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Right? So
column6: looking at the simple sentence like

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: a dog is chasing a boy on the playground.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _We don't have any problems understanding this sentence
column6: but _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: imagine what the computer would have to do in order to understand it.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For in general
column6: it would have to do the following. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _First
column6: it would have to know dog is a noun

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: this is a code lexile analysis or part of speech tagging. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: we need to pick out the
column7: the syntaxing categories of those words. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: that's a first step. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _After that
column6: we're going to figure out the structure of the sentence. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So for example
column6: here it shows that a and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: dog would go together to form a noun phrase.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: we won't have dog and is to go first

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: there are some structures that are not just right. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But
column6: this structure shows what we might get if we look at the sentence and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: try to interpret the sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Some words would go together first
column6: and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: then they will go together with other words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So here
column6: we show we have noun phrases as intermediate components and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: then verb phrases.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Finally
column6: we have a sentence. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: you get this structure
column7: we need to do something called a syntactic analysis

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: or parsing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: we may have a parser

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: a computer program that would automatically create this structure.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _At this point
column6: you would know the structure of this sentence

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: still you don't know the meaning of the sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: we have to go further through semantic analysis. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In our mind

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: we usually can map such a sentence to what we already know in our knowledge base.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And for example
column6: you might imagine a dog that looks like that

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: there's a boy and there's some activity here.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But for computer
column6: will have to use symbols to denote that. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: All right.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: we would use the symbol d1 to denote a dog. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: b1 to denote a boy
column7: and then p1 to denote the playground

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now
column6: there is also a chasing activity that's happening here

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _we have the relation chasing here
column6: that connects all these symbols. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: this is how a computer would obtain some understanding of this sentence. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now from this representation
column6: we could also further infer some other things

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _and we might indeed
column6: naturally think of something else when we read text. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: this is call inference. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So for example
column6: if you believe that if someone's being chased and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: this person might be scared.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: All right.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _With this rule

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: you can see computers could also infer that this boy may be scared.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: this is some extra knowledge that you would infer based on _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: some understanding of the text.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _You can even go further to understand the
column6: why the person said this sentence. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: this has to do with the use of language. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: All right.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: This is called pragmatic analysis.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In order to understand the speech actor of a sentence
column6: all right

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: we say something to basically achieve some goal.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: There's some purpose there and this has to do with the use of language.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In this case
column6: the person who said _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: the sentence might be reminding another person to bring back the dog.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: That could be one possible intent.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _To reach this level of understanding
column6: we would require all these steps. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: a computer would have to go through all these steps in order to _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: completely understand this sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Yet
column6: we humans have no trouble with understand that. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _We instantly
column6: will get everything
column7: and there is a reason for that. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _That's because we have a large knowledge base in our brain
column6: and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: we use common sense knowledge to help interpret the sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Computers
column6: unfortunately
column7: are hard to obtain such understanding. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: They don't have such a knowledge base.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: They are still incapable of doing reasoning and uncertainties.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: that makes natural language processing difficult for computers. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But
column6: the fundamental reason why the natural language processing is difficult _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: for computers is simple because natural language has not been designed for

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: computers.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _They
column6: they
column7: natural languages are designed for us to communicate. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: There are other languages designed for computers.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: program languages. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Those are harder for us
column6: right. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: natural languages is designed to make our communication efficient. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _As a result
column6: we omit a lot of common sense knowledge _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: because we assume everyone knows about that.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _We also keep a lot of ambiguities because we assume the receiver
column6: or _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _the hearer could know how to discern an ambiguous word

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: based on the knowledge or the context.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: There's no need to invent a different word for different meanings.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We could overload the same word with different meanings without the problem.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Because of these reasons

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: this makes every step in natural language of processing difficult for computers.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Ambiguity's the main difficulty
column6: and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _common sense reasoning is often required
column6: that's also hard. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: let me give you some examples of challenges here. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Conceded the word-level ambiguities.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: The same word can have different syntactical categories.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: design can be a noun or a verb. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: The word root may have multiple meanings.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: square root in math sense
column7: or the root of a plant. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: You might be able to think of other meanings.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: There are also syntactical ambiguities.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: the main topic of this lecture

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _can actually be interpreted in two ways
column6: in terms of the structure. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Think for a moment and see if you can figure that out.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _We usually think of this as processing of natural languages
column6: but _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _you could also think of this as you say
column6: language process is natural. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Right. So
column6: this is example of syntatic ambiguity. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Where we have different structures that can be

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: applied to the same sequence of words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Another example of ambiguous sentence is the following

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: a man saw a boy with a telescope.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now
column6: in this case

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _All right
column6: this is called a prepositional phrase attachment ambiguity

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: or PP attachment ambiguity.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now
column6: we generally don't have a problem with these ambiguities because we have _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: a lot of background knowledge to help us disintegrate the ambiguity.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Another example of difficulty is anaphora resolution.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: think about the sentence like John persuaded Bill to buy a TV for himself. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _The question here is
column6: does himself refer to John or Bill? _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So again
column6: this is something that you have to use some background or _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: the context to figure out.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Finally
column6: presupposition is another problem. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Consider the sentence
column6: he has quit smoking. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Now this obviously implies he smoked before.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: imagine a computer wants to understand all the subtle differences and meanings. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: They would have to use a lot of knowledge to figure that out.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _It also would have to maintain a large knowl
column6: knowledge base of odd meanings of _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: words and how they are connected to our common sense knowledge of the word.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So this is why it's very difficult.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So as a result we are still not perfect.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In fact
column6: far from perfect in understanding natural languages using computers. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So this slide sort of gives a simplified view of state of the art technologies.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We can do part of speech tagging pretty well.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: I showed minus 7% accuracy here. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Now this number is obviously based on a certain data set
column6: so _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: don't take this literally.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _All right
column6: this just shows that we could do it pretty well. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: But it's still not perfect.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In terms of parsing
column6: we can do partial parsing pretty well. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _That means we can get noun phrase structures or verb phrase structure
column6: or _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: some segment of the sentence understood correctly in terms of the structure.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: in some evaluation results we have seen about 90% _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: accuracy in terms of partial parsing of sentences.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Again
column6: I have to say
column7: these numbers are relative to the data set. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In some other data sets
column6: the numbers might be lower. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Most of existing work has been evaluated using news data set.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And so
column6: a lot of these numbers are more or less biased towards news data. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Think about social media data.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: The accuracy likely is lower.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In terms of semantic analysis

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: we are far from being able to do a complete understanding of a sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: But we have some techniques that would allow us to do

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: partial understanding of the sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: I could mention some of them. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: we have techniques that can allow us to extract the entities and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: relations mentioned in text or articles.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: recognizing the mentions of people

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _organizations
column6: et cetera in text. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Right? So this is called entity extraction.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We may be able to recognize the relations.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: this person visited that per

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Or
column6: this person met that person
column7: or this company acquired another company. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Such relations can be extracted by using the current and

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: natural languaging processing techniques.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _They are not perfect
column6: but they can do well for some entities. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Some entities are harder than others.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We can also do word sentence disintegration to some extent.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _We have to figure out whether this word in this sentence would have certain meaning

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _and in another context

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: the computer could figure out that it has a different meaning.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Again
column6: it's not perfect but you can do something in that direction. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: We can also do sentiment analysis meaning

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: to figure out whether sentence is positive or negative.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _This is a special use for
column6: for review analysis for example. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So these examples of semantic analysis.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And they help us to obtain partial understanding of the sentences.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Right? It's not

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _giving us a complete understanding as I showed before for the sentence
column6: but _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: it will still help us gain understanding of the content and these can be useful.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In terms of inference
column6: we are not yet there

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: probably because of the general difficulty of inference and uncertainties.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: This is a general challenge in artificial intelligence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: That's probably also because we don't have complete semantic reimplementation for

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: natural language text.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So this is hard.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Yet in some domains
column6: perhaps in limited domains when you have a lot of _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _restrictions on the world of users
column6: you may be to may be able to perform _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _inference to some extent
column6: but in general we cannot really do that reliably. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Speech act analysis is also far from being done
column6: and _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: we can only do that analysis for very special cases.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: this roughly gives you some idea about the state of the art. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And let me also talk a little bit about what we can't do.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: and so we can't even do 100% part of speech tagging. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _This looks like a simple task
column6: but think about the example here

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: the two uses of off may have different syntactic categories if you try

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: to make a fine grain distinctions.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: It's not that easy to figure out such differences.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: It's also hard to do general complete the parsing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And
column6: again this same sentence that you saw before is example. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _This
column6: this ambiguity can be very hard to disambiguate. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And you can imagine example where you have to use a lot of knowledge i

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: in the context of the sentence or

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _from the background in order to figure out the
column6: who actually had the telescope. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So is
column6: i

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And in cases when the sentence is very long
column6: imagine it has four or _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _five prepositional phrases
column6: then there are even more possibilities to figure out. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: It's also harder to precise deep semantic analysis.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So here's example.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In this sentence
column6: John owns a restaurant
column7: how do we define owns exactly? _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _The word
column6: own
column8: is something that we can understand but _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: it's very hard to precisely describe the meaning of own for computers.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So as a result we have robust and

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: general natural language processing techniques that can process a lot of text

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _data in a shallow way
column6: meaning we only do superficial analysis. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _For example
column6: part of s

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _partial parsing
column6: or recognizing sentiment. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And those are not deep understanding because we're not really

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: understanding the exact meaning of the sentence.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _On the other hand
column6: the deep understanding techniques tend not to scale up well

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: meaning that they would fail on some unrestricted text.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And if you don't restrict the text domain or

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _the use of words
column6: then these techniques tend not to work well. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _They may work well
column6: based on machine learning techniques on the data _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: that are similar to the training data that the program has been trained on.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: But they generally wouldn't work well on the data that are very different from

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: the training data.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So this pretty much summarizes the state of the art of natural language processing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Of course
column6: within such a short amount of time
column7: we can't really give you a

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _a complete view of any of it
column6: which is a big field
column7: and either expect that to have

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: to see multiple courses on natural language processing topic itself.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But
column6: because of it's relevance to the topic that we talked about it's useful for _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: you to know the background in case you haven't been exposed to that.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: what does that mean for text retrieval? _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _Well
column6: in text retrieval we are dealing with all kinds of text. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: It's very hard to restrict the text to a certain domain.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And we also are often dealing with a lot of text data
column6: so that means. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _The NLP techniques must be general
column6: robust

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: just implies today we can only use fairly shallow NLP techniques for text retrieval.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In fact

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: most search engines today use something called a bag of words representation.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Now this is probably the simplest representation you can probably think of.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: That is to turn text data into simply a bag of words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Meaning we will keep the individual words but we'll ignore all the orders of words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And we'll keep duplicated occurrences of words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So this is called a bag of words representation.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _When you represent the text in this way
column6: you ignore a lot about the information

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: and that just makes it harder

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: to understand the exact meaning of a sentence because we've lost the order.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But yet
column6: this representation tends to actually work pretty well for _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: most search tasks.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And this is partly because the search task is not all that difficult.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _If you see matching of some of the query words in a text document
column6: chances _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _are that that document is about the topic
column6: although there are exceptions

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So in comparison some other tasks
column6: for example machine translation

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _you to understand the language accurately
column6: otherwise the translation would be wrong. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So in comparison

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: search tasks are solved relatively easy such a representation is often sufficient.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And that's also the representation that the major search engines today

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: like Google or Bing are using.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Of course I put in in parentheses but not all.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Of course there are many queries that are not answered well by the current search

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _engines
column6: and they do require a representation _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: that would go beyond bag of words representation.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _That would require more natural language processing
column6: to be done. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: There is another reason why we have not used the sophisticated NLP

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _techniques in modern search engines
column6: and that's because some retrieval techniques _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: actually naturally solve the problem of NLP.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So
column6: one example

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Think about a word like java.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: It could mean coffee or it could mean program language.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: If you look at the word alone it would be ambiguous.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _But when the user uses the water in the query
column6: usually there are other words. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: For example I'm looking for usage of Java applet.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: When I have applet there that implies Java means program language.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And that context can help us naturally

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _prefer documents where Java is referring to program language

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: because those documents would probably match applet as well.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _If java occurs in the document in a way that means coffee

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _then you would never match applet
column6: or with very small probability. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Right. So this is a case when some retrieval

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: techniques naturally achieve the goal of word sense disambiguation.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Another example is some technique called

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: feedback which we will talk about later in some of the lectures.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _This tech
column6: technique would allow us to add additional words to the query. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And those additional words could be related to the query words.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And these words can help match documents where the original query words

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: have not occurred.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _So this achieves
column6: to some extent

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: So those techniques also helped us

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: bypass some of the difficulties in natural language processing.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _However
column6: in the long run
column7: we still need deeper natural language processing _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: techniques in order to improve the accuracy of the current search engines.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And it's particularly needed for complex search tasks
column6: or for question answering. _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Google has recently launched a knowledge graph.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And this is one step toward that goal

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: because knowledge graph would contain entities and their relations.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And this goes beyond the simple bag of words representation.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And such technique should help us improve the search engine utility significantly

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: although this is a still open topic for research and exploration.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _In sum
column6: in this lecture we'll talk about what is NLP and we've talked _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _about the state of the art techniques
column6: what we can do

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: _And finally
column6: we also explained why bag of words representation _

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: remains the dominant representation used in modern search engines even though

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: deeper NLP would be needed for future search engines.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: If you want to know more you can take a look at some additional readings.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: I only cited one here.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: And that's a good starting point though.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
text: Thanks.

name: 2 - 1 - 1.1 Natural Language Content Analysis (00-21-05).srt
